td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: [I]n the middle of this Course we were oblig'd to put back & encamp on Account of wind, & here our Guide gave a fresh determination that he would proceed no farther[.] Yesterday he came into our Tent & gave us an Acct of the Carryg places to Portage de l'Isle, which he made amt to 66 besides 6 Lakes, for which favour he requested a drink, a little of which was given him: but my Gentleman afterwds grew so violently outrageous as to threaten destruction to every thing abt him, by turns flattering, threatning, & then endeavouring to Theive & break the Canoes. Tho' the fairest promises & kindnest usage has been given this man, it is all to no purpose, for at the very instt I was writing the above one of our men has brought an Acct of his having found a 9 Gall. keg ½ full of mix'd liquor in ye woods, which he found means to Steal, tho' a sharp look out is kept, I entic'd the father & Son to the place, by telling them I had found ye fresh track of a Moose, they came very unsuspectingly to the place, but how great was his Surprize when I shew'd him the keg of liquor: after upbraiding him with his Perfidy, I oblig'd the father to carry it back to our Baggage, & as to the Son he took to the woods & was of no of hear'd of no more for sevl hours. We were soon afterwds outwardly Good friends, but experience says no confidence can be put in this Villain.

June 24 Thursday. The continuance of the wind prevented us from proceeding this day before it was late in the afternoon, when we set off, our Indn Guide in Co finish'd the last Course mentd yesterday, at the end of which pass'd the point leaving a small isld on our Right. After turning the point, we went WbN3m. to a place, where a Settlemt has formerly been erected, but no Traces are now to be seen of it except the wood being cut away, here the dilatory proceedings of the Guide oblig'd us to encamp. Lat.obsd 49°42'[.] The Knavery of the Indn together with the continual deceit he has practic'd on us, determin'd us to go on witht him, especially as the N° of his family lays very heavy on our provisions: finding us thus resolvd, he pray'd to be employ'd, but we told him this could not be done, unless he would promise most faithfully to be good & honest; on this condition we promis'd him ev'ry kindness & good paymt & on the contrary told him he must leave us without paymt in goods, but a severe paymt in Stripes – he promis'd ev'ry thing we could desire – how long he may keep his word time must determine, but nothing but absolute necessity could induce a Person to have any thing to do with a man possess'd of every bad Quality, & whose mind is as black as his outward Skin.

25 Friday. From the old French House No to a point on the main shore 4m. pass'd 2 islds on our right, & a small River on the left – from hence across a Bay to a lofty Peek of perpendicular rocks NbE7m. sevl islds in the Bay on our left, & high mountaneous land, from the Peek 3½m. NNE. to a point, sevl islds on our Right pass'd another place, where a House had formerly been erected. From the Peek we enter'd a Strait abt ½m. wide, islds on the Right, the main of the left.
